content.title: Cardiac CT (Computed Tomography)
content.summary: Non-invasive cardiac imaging modality using X-ray computed tomography to evaluate coronary artery anatomy, coronary artery calcium, cardiac structure, and plan interventions such as TAVR
key_points: Coronary CT angiography (CCTA) is first-line for stable chest pain with intermediate pretest probability
Coronary artery calcium (CAC) scoring quantifies atherosclerotic burden (Agatston score)
CAC score of 0 indicates very low 10-year cardiovascular event risk (<1%)
CCTA requires heart rate control (target <60 bpm) and beta-blocker premedication
CAD-RADS standardized reporting system grades stenosis severity (0-5)
Excellent negative predictive value (>99%) for ruling out significant CAD
Essential for TAVR planning (annular sizing, vascular access assessment)
Radiation exposure: ~3-5 mSv for CCTA, <1 mSv for CAC scoring

statement.text: Cardiac computed tomography encompasses coronary CT angiography (CCTA) for evaluating coronary artery stenosis and coronary artery calcium (CAC) scoring for cardiovascular risk stratification. CCTA has excellent negative predictive value for excluding significant coronary artery disease in patients with stable chest pain and intermediate pretest probability. CAC scoring quantifies calcified atherosclerotic plaque using the Agatston method and reclassifies cardiovascular risk. Cardiac CT is also essential for structural heart disease evaluation and TAVR procedural planning.
statement.formal: CCTA indication = Stable chest pain + Intermediate pretest probability | CAC score interpretation: 0 = very low risk, 1-99 = mild, 100-399 = moderate, ≥400 = severe

explanation.intuition: Cardiac CT takes rapid X-ray images of the heart synchronized to the ECG, allowing visualization of the coronary arteries without invasive catheterization. For CCTA, contrast dye is injected to opacify the coronary arteries. For calcium scoring, no contrast is needed - the scanner simply detects calcified plaque in coronary vessel walls. Think of it as a 'non-invasive angiogram' that can identify blockages or confirm arteries are clean.
explanation.key_insight: The key strength of CCTA is its negative predictive value - if CCTA shows no significant stenosis, you can confidently rule out obstructive CAD without invasive angiography. However, positive findings may require functional testing or invasive confirmation due to limited positive predictive value. CAC scoring is most valuable when it changes management - a zero score in borderline-risk patients may justify avoiding statin therapy.
explanation.technical_details: Modern 256+ slice CT scanners acquire the entire heart in a single heartbeat. ECG-gated acquisition freezes cardiac motion. Prospective triggering reduces radiation by only imaging during diastole. Iterative reconstruction algorithms improve image quality while reducing dose. Beta-blockers slow heart rate to <60 bpm for optimal image quality. Sublingual nitroglycerin dilates coronary arteries. Iodinated contrast (60-100 mL) is required for CCTA but not CAC scoring.

definitions_glossary.cardiac_ct: Computed tomography imaging of the heart, including coronary CT angiography and calcium scoring
definitions_glossary.coronary_ct_angiography: CCTA - contrast-enhanced CT imaging to evaluate coronary artery stenosis and plaque morphology
definitions_glossary.calcium_scoring: Non-contrast CT quantifying calcified atherosclerotic plaque in coronary arteries
definitions_glossary.agatston_score: Method for quantifying coronary artery calcium based on area and density of calcified plaques
definitions_glossary.cad_rads: Coronary Artery Disease Reporting and Data System - standardized CCTA stenosis grading (0-5)
definitions_glossary.prospective_triggering: ECG-gated acquisition imaging only during diastole to reduce radiation dose
definitions_glossary.retrospective_gating: Continuous imaging throughout cardiac cycle allowing functional assessment
definitions_glossary.fractional_flow_reserve_ct: FFR-CT - computational fluid dynamics to assess hemodynamic significance of stenosis
definitions_glossary.hounsfield_units: CT attenuation measurement scale; calcium appears bright (>130 HU in coronary arteries)
definitions_glossary.blooming_artifact: Apparent enlargement of calcified plaques on CT, may overestimate stenosis
definitions_glossary.motion_artifact: Image blur from cardiac motion; minimized by heart rate control
definitions_glossary.beam_hardening: Artifact from dense structures (calcium, stents) affecting adjacent tissue appearance
definitions_glossary.iodinated_contrast: Intravenous dye containing iodine used for vessel opacification in CCTA
definitions_glossary.ecg_gating: Synchronizing image acquisition to the cardiac cycle for motion-free imaging

pathophysiology.mechanism: Cardiac CT leverages the differential X-ray attenuation of tissues. Iodinated contrast fills the coronary lumen allowing visualization of stenosis. Calcium in atherosclerotic plaques has high attenuation (bright on CT). ECG synchronization ensures images are acquired during diastole when the heart is relatively still. Modern multi-detector CT acquires thin slices that are reconstructed into 3D coronary images.
technical_principles: X-ray tube rotates around patient while table advances (helical acquisition)
Multiple detector rows acquire data simultaneously (256-320 slices)
ECG synchronization triggers acquisition during cardiac diastole
Iodinated contrast opacifies blood pool and coronary lumens
Multi-planar reconstruction generates coronary artery images
Curved planar reformation follows coronary artery course
Volume rendering creates 3D visualization of cardiac anatomy

image_quality_factors.breath_hold: Patient must hold breath 5-10 seconds during acquisition
image_quality_factors.contrast_timing: Bolus tracking or test bolus ensures optimal opacification
image_quality_factors.arrhythmias: PVCs and atrial fibrillation degrade image quality

primary: Stable chest pain with intermediate pretest probability (15-65%)
Acute chest pain with low-intermediate probability in ED (HEART score 4-6)
New-onset heart failure to evaluate ischemic etiology
contraindications: Known severe CAD (CCTA won't change management)
Inability to achieve adequate heart rate control

cac_scoring_indications: Intermediate ASCVD risk (7.5-19.9%) when statin decision is uncertain
Borderline ASCVD risk (5-7.5%) to guide shared decision-making
Family history of premature CAD in otherwise low-risk patients
Not indicated if already on statin or known CAD

cad_rads_classification.modifiers: N = non-diagnostic, S = stent, G = graft, V = vulnerable plaque

stable_cad_evaluation.workflow: CCTA as first-line for intermediate pretest probability
stable_cad_evaluation.interpretation: CAD-RADS 0-2 requires no further testing; 3-4 may need functional testing or ICA
stable_cad_evaluation.ffr_ct: Computational FFR available for intermediate stenosis (CAD-RADS 3)

acute_coronary_syndrome.indication: Low-intermediate risk chest pain in ED (alternative to stress testing)
acute_coronary_syndrome.value: Rapid rule-out of significant CAD; enables safe discharge

structural_heart_disease.tavr_planning: Annular sizing, coronary height, vascular access, calcium distribution

calcium_score_interpretation.score_0: Very low risk; CAD very unlikely; may defer statin in borderline risk
calcium_score_interpretation.score_100_399: Moderate atherosclerosis; consider intensifying risk factor modification
calcium_score_interpretation.score_400_plus: Extensive atherosclerosis; high risk; aggressive medical therapy indicated
calcium_score_interpretation.score_1000_plus: Severe atherosclerosis; consider functional testing for symptoms

radiation_safety.ccta: 2-5 mSv with modern prospective protocols (equivalent to 1-2 years background radiation)
radiation_safety.reduction_techniques: Prospective triggering, iterative reconstruction, tube current modulation

skos.scopeNote: Covers coronary CT angiography, calcium scoring, and structural heart CT applications; excludes cardiac MRI and nuclear imaging
skos.example: A 55-year-old with atypical chest pain and intermediate pretest probability undergoes CCTA showing CAD-RADS 1 (mild non-obstructive plaque); no further testing needed, medical therapy optimized

medicalCode.description: CT heart without contrast for quantification of coronary calcium

learning_objectives: Identify appropriate indications for coronary CT angiography vs calcium scoring
Interpret CAD-RADS classification and guide subsequent management
Apply calcium score results to cardiovascular risk stratification
Recognize limitations and contraindications of cardiac CT
Describe TAVR planning elements assessed by cardiac CT
clinical_pearls: CCTA is first-line for stable chest pain with intermediate pretest probability
CAC score of 0 = very low risk; may defer statin in borderline-risk patients
Beta-blocker to HR <60 + nitroglycerin before CCTA for optimal images
CAD-RADS 0-2 generally needs no further testing; ≥3 may need functional assessment
Calcium causes blooming artifact - may overestimate stenosis severity
FFR-CT can non-invasively assess hemodynamic significance of intermediate lesions
CCTA excellent for ruling OUT CAD but less reliable for ruling IN significant stenosis

board_yield.usmle_step3: High - risk stratification, appropriate use criteria
board_yield.cardiology_boards: Very High - detailed interpretation, FFR-CT, structural applications

common_misconceptions: All chest pain needs invasive angiography (false - CCTA is first-line for many patients)
CAC score 0 means no plaque (false - non-calcified plaque may still exist, but rare)
Higher CAC score always means more stenosis (false - extensive calcium may not cause significant stenosis)
CCTA can replace invasive angiography (false - CCTA for diagnosis, ICA for intervention)
